Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 500 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer for Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Tadeusz Malinski from Ohio University and colleagues Eric Masson, Stephen Bergmeier, Michael Jensen and Jennifer Hines will acquire a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer (11.7 Tesla magnet, 54 mm bore, with active shielding.) The new spectrometer would have gradient shimming, 4-radiofrequency channel, a variable temperature unit, and three probes: an inverse triple resonance microprobe for the observation of 1H while decoupling 13C and 15N nuclei and a multinuclear broadband Fluorine Observe SmartProbe. The project is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) study of highly complex macromolecules from natural products and from synthetic preparations; (b) synthesis of medicinally relevant natural and unnatural products; (c) study of recognition properties and applications of the Cucurbituril family of macrocycles using supramolecular chemistry; (d) identification of highly substituted polypyridine-metal complexes that have a large number of overlapping aromatic protons in spectra collected at lower field strength; (e) use of paramagnetic NMR techniques; (f) development of RNA-targeted ligands; and (g) nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathways.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research and will impact a large number of students including some from the Appalachian Ohio region and also industrial partnerships. Collaborations will expose students from the University of Rio Grande and Shawnee State to the scientific capabilities of NMR instrumentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation provided funding to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Ohio University to purchase a new 500 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer. NMR spectroscopy is the sole technique available to chemists that allows the exact determination of the nature and structure of molecules synthesized in the laboratory. Maintaining a state-of-the-art NMR facility is thus absolutely critical to teaching and research in chemistry.

The new spectrometer replaced an antiquated instrument purchased in 1996 that had been obsolete and dysfunctional for several years, and that was causing long downtime periods, during which research would come to a standstill. Since its installation in November 2014, the new spectrometer has been used by all co-PIs, as well as additional colleagues and students in the department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, other departments and colleges, and outside the university. It has been involved in a wide range of projects, such as the structural determination of self-assembling polymers, the monitoring of reactions taking place into the cavity of other molecules, the characterization of metallic complexes with unusual magnetic properties, the structural analysis of bioactive and antimicrobial agents, the classification and characterization of plant extracts, the evaluation of nanosensors used in the diagnosis of cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases, and the characterization of a molecular car to be driven on a gold surface using the tip of a scanning tunneling microscope.

Fourty graduate, undergraduate and exchange students from inside and outside the department have taken a new NMR spectroscopy class dedicated to training on the new NSF-funded instrument. The user base is also growing steadily since the inauguration of the spectrometer. Workshops for users coming from outside the university and the industry are being successfully organized on a yearly basis. The NMR spectrometer is also used to produce high quality NMR spectra for the sophomore organic chemistry course, and hands-on time on the instrument is included in undergraduate and graduate organic and inorganic chemistry courses.

In conclusion, the NSF-funded NMR spectrometer will keep playing a uniquely and critically important role for years to come in research and teaching in the department of chemistry and biochemistry at Ohio University and beyond.
